hedline.hl1: Speaking Out Against A 7-Eleven for Holmdel

abstract.p: Dale R Thompson letter supports June 18 article on struggle to prevent opening of 7-Eleven convenience store near schools in Holmdel, NJ (S)

block.p: Thank you for your article on our struggle with the 7-Eleven Corporation (''Taking on 7-Eleven in Holmdel,'' June 18). As the father of a child in the New School and as co-director of New High School, I have found this battle to be of utmost importance to our school and the residential neighborhood around us.

The New School and New High School differ from other schools because we devote much of our curriculum to the importance of building a cooperative community. We teach our students that the process of building a community requires understanding the needs of the people with whom they work.

Thank you for your article on our struggle with the 7-Eleven Corporation (''Taking on 7-Eleven in Holmdel,'' June 18). As the father of a child in the New School and as co-director of New High School, I have found this battle to be of utmost importance to our school and the residential neighborhood around us.

The New School and New High School differ from other schools because we devote much of our curriculum to the importance of building a cooperative community. We teach our students that the process of building a community requires understanding the needs of the people with whom they work.

Your article captured 7-Eleven's confusion about what our community needs. Statements by a Southland Corporation spokeswoman, Margaret Chabris, demonstrates this confusion. She states: ''We know what the concerns of the school and residents are, and we have been more than willing to address them.''

Had Southland, owners of the 7-Eleven chain, done a little research, some of her confusion might have been alleviated. At an early meeting, 7-Eleven's representative was surprised to learn they were seeking use variances on a property adjacent to a school. Later they discovered they had to redo a traffic study because they could not figure out that the school had half days on Wednesdays.

This is not the way to work with a community. Ms. Chabris recites platitudes about working with the school and residents while 7-Eleven and its lawyer alternately bully and bore the planning board of Holmdel. After a year of town meetings there has not been a single person who has come out in favor of building a 7-Eleven at Laurel Avenue and Middle Road, except for expert witnesses paid for by 7-Eleven.
